texts.shortText:
Fairly large, very fat, cushion-like species with poorly developed arms and a central dorsal opening. Colour yellow to orange, often with brown spots or blotches.

The dorsal surface (as in all members of this family) consists of a unique double layer, the normal lower layer bearing long, branched spines which support a second thin outer membrane, thus creating a cavity which is used as a brood chamber. The dorsal chamber is ventilated through a central round opening and specimens can be observed ’breathing’ in and out of this hole.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
Absent intertidally, but occurs from a few metres depth to about 370 m on both rock and sand. Uncommon and usually seen singly. Secretes copious toxic mucus when disturbed to deter predators.

Thought to feed on a variety of invertebrates by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it over the prey. The diet of this species has not been studied, but related species in the Northern Hemisphere feed on sponges, molluscs and ascidians.

Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Like many other members of this family this species broods it young in the dorsal chamber. The details of this process have not been studied, but in related North American species the young are considerably larger than the eggs from which they develop, suggesting that developing juveniles must obtain nutrition directly from the mother (or by eating one another!).

The large size, fat cushion-like form and respiratory aperture in the centre of the dorsal surface make it unlikely that Pteraster species would be confused with other regional starfish. There are three other deep water species in the region though (P. affinis, P. flabellifera and P. fornicatus), but these all occur below about 300 m water depth.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 224).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 84).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 178)
